Award.AwardTitle: FESD Type I: The Dynamics of Earth System Oxygenation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Oxygen, in the form of the molecule O2, is abundant in the Earth's atmosphere and oceans, where it is vital for all multi-cellular life, including humans. However, O2 was nearly absent from the atmosphere and oceans during the first half of Earth's history. In the past decade, we solidified our understanding of when the prolonged and complex transition to the modern, O2-rich environment began. However, the cause of this so-called "Great Oxidation Event" (GOE) and later changes in O2 remains one of the major mysteries in Earth System Science. Solving it is of more than academic interest because it will help us understand how the Earth supports life, and provide insights and perspective on some of the environmental challenges posed by human activity. This project will tackle this challenge by combining new data and calculations that reach from the Earth's core to the top of the atmosphere to develop a comprehensive model of the geochemical cycle of O2 that can explain the GOE.

The specific research program is motivated by an emerging consensus that biological O2 production began long before the GOE. If so, then the GOE was most likely triggered by a change in O2 consumption. Various lines of reasoning point to changes in the flux of O2-reactive material from the Earth's mantle, perhaps driven by the gradual but inexorable cooling of the planet's interior. However, the specific changes and their causes are unclear and debated. The project team will refine and test a number of hypotheses proposed in the past decade. To do so it necessarily integrates: models of atmospheric chemistry; records of Earth's surface O2 history developed from inorganic and organic geochemical proxies; laboratory calibrations of these proxies; geochemical analyses of samples from the lithosphere and mantle; seismic reconstructions of Earth's interior structure; geodynamic models of mantle mixing and evolution; thermodynamic calculations; and findings from mineral physics experiments. Researchers in these disciplinary communities rarely collaborate. Therefore, the work will be scientifically transformative.

The project team aims to extend this transformation beyond its members and even beyond the geosciences. In addition to the typical training and dissemination activities, we will foster communication and integration across disciplinary boundaries by: conducting open, online "workshops without walls" on the O2 puzzle; perform scholarly research into our collaborative research challenges and practices to identify and disseminate best practices for transdisciplinary team science; and develop, deploy, and assess a teacher professional development (PD) program centered on how scientists communicate across diverse disciplinary divides to answer complex questions. These broader activities, together with the science research program, will advance a holistic vision of the Earth System that, while of broad societal importance, is often discussed but rarely realized.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Context: Today, 21% of Earth's atmosphere consists of molecular oxygen - the O2 molecule. Without this large concentration of O2 in the atmosphere, animal life could not exist. Understanding what controls O2 and how O2 has changed with time is therefore of fundamental importance to understanding how Earth became the world that it is today, where modern ecosystems can flourish. This knowledge is also fundamentally important to guide the search for Earth-like worlds orbiting other stars, which is one of the most rapidly advancing areas of science today.

During the first half of Earth's history, O2 was nearly absent in the atmosphere. This situation changed irreversibly about 2.4 billion years ago. The "Great Oxidation Event" (aka the "GOE") marks the transition from a world in which O2 was scarce to one in which it rose inexorably to eventually reach modern levels. This was the most profound environmental transformation since the emergence of life itself.

The interplay of forces that drove this transformation remains poorly understood. We know that O2-producing photosynthesis had to evolve to provide the O2 for the GOE. But we also know that this supply of O2 had to overwhelm the ongoing supply of materials that consume O2 coming from Earth's interior. How and why did this balance change when it did? 

To tackle this foundational question in geoscience, this NSF project brought together ~ 20 geoscientists, spanning different subdisciplines, from 5 universities. The project was remarkably successful as summarized below.

Intellectual Merit: The project team generated more than 150 peer reviewed publications. Through this work, they delivered two major breakthroughs:

1. Revising our knowledge of environmental O2 before the GOE, documenting the early occurrence of "whiffs" of O2 and the implications for the evolution of O2-producing photosynthesis. This part of the project centered on the analysis of recently recovered sedimentary rocks from 2.7 - 2.5 billion years ago, as well as some other sample suites. The team's work focused on both organic and inorganic chemistry in these materials. Organic analyses were carried out with unprecedented control over contamination from modern materials. This work showed that prior use of organic molecules extracted from ancient rocks to search for evidence of pre-GOE O2 production was plagued by contamination and could not be relied upon. However, parallel work by the team on a variety of novel inorganic tracers provided compelling new evidence of multiple episodes of probably transient environmental O2. These "whiffs" of O2 may have been a pervasive feature of the pre-GOE world. The provide strong evidence that O2 was being produced biologically for hundreds of millions of years before the GOE. What, then, kept O2 from rising? What delayed the onset of the GOE?

2. Reviving a classic-but-disfavored theory that linked the GOE to changes in the makeup of volcanic gases. One of the oldest hypotheses to explain the GOE invoked a progressive change in the chemical composition of volcanic gases, stemming from slowly evolving chemistry of Earth's mantle. Specifically, that the redox state of Earth's upper mantle increased gradually over time. According to this hypothesis, before the GOE volcanic gases derived from the mantle consumed O2 rapidly enough to prevent O2 accumulation, with this balance shifting after the GOE. This theory fell into disfavor when previous studies failed to find evidence of the hypothesized change in mantle chemistry. However, the uncertainties in these prior studies were too large to fully resolve the issue. The project team developed a new approach to assess change in mantle redox state over time. Its application revealed a gradual change that was too small for previous methods to detect. When incorporated into atmospheric evolution models, the discovered change turned out to be just enough to account for both the occurrence and timing of the GOE. It now seems likely that change in Earth's mantle chemistry accounted for the delay between life's first production of O2 and the GOE, and the timing of Earth's transition to being an oxygenated world.

Broader Impacts: The project advanced four major broader impacts:

1. The project's basic geoscience insights will shape how astronomers assess the prospects for O2 evolution on extrasolar Earth-like planets. This will eventually have a direct impact on which worlds are targeted for spectroscopic investigation - an impact far beyond the purview of the project team.

2. The project broke new ground in collaborative methods across institutions, both technologically and sociologically - the latter by including a language scholar as part of the team who researched the seldom-appreciated but serious linguistic challenges of research across geoscience subdisciplines.

3. The project advanced the training of approx. 30 students and postdocs, roughly 1/3 female. A number of them were mentored into tenure-track jobs by project's end.

4. The project informed the development of a suite of immersive virtual field trips of locations documenting Earth's history (http://vft.asu.edu)
